title: Yao Zhong Ping v Teambuild Construction Pte Ltd [2003] SGDC 326
content:
Yao Zhong Ping v Teambuild Construction Pte Ltd
[2003] SGDC 326
 
 
Case Number
 
:
 
DC Suit 131/2003, DCA 48/2003, 49/2003
 
 
 
Decision Date
 
:
 
30 December 2003
 
 
 
Tribunal/Court
 
:
 
District Court
 
 
 
Coram
 
:
 
 
Kathryn Low Lye Fong
 
 
 
 
Counsel Name(s)
 
:
 
 Lin Shiu Yi and Loo Eng Teck (Hoh Law Corporation) for the plaintiff; Michael Eu Hai Meng (Comlaw LLC) for the defendants 
 
 
 
Parties
 
:
 
 Yao Zhong Ping — Teambuild Construction Pte Ltd 
 
 
 
Tort
  – 
Negligence
  – 
Industrial accident
  – 
Occupier's liability
  – 
Breach of statutory duty under Factories Act (Cap 104)
 
 
Damages
  – 
Loss of future earnings or loss of earning capacity
 
 
 
Background
 
 
1
          The plaintiff, Yao Zhong Ping is a Chinese National who was employed by the defendants, Teambuild Construction Pte Ltd as a construction carpenter.  The defendants were at the material time, the main contractor involved in the upgrading of Radin Mas Primary School situated at No 1 Bukit Purmei Avenue (hereinafter referred to as “the work site”).  He claimed that he was injured, when he fell off a scaffold structure that was erected by the defendants or their agents, while he was carrying out his work at the work site, on 10 April 2002 at about 4.15pm.  The scaffold was made up of metal frames, I-shaped aluminium-alloy beams that were installed parallel and secured along the scaffold frames.  The plaintiff was instructed to nail timber runners at intervals across the aluminium beams at the time.  He alleged that in the midst of working, one of the beams suddenly gave way and he fell 4 m to the staircase landing below.  He suffered injuries to his face and back.  The plaintiff claimed that the defendants and/or their employees, servants or agents for whom the defendants are vicariously liable, were in breach of their statutory duty of care under the Factories Act (Cap 104), as occupiers and/or common law duty of care to the plaintiff.  The particulars of negligence were as pleaded in the statement of claim at BP3 to 5.  He also sought to rely on the doctrine of 
res ipsa loquitur
.  He claimed that he suffered injuries and disabilities as particularised and claimed general damages, special damages, pre-trial loss of earnings, interest and costs from the defendants.
2          The defendants denied that the scaffold, was erected by them or their servants or agents and also that the plaintiff was entitled to rely on the doctrine of 
res ipsa loquitur
.  In fact, the structure from which the plaintiff fell was not a scaffold, but a formwork. They claimed that the accident was caused solely or contributed to by the negligence of the plaintiff in failing to follow instructions or safety regulations and failing to take reasonable precaution for his own safety.  They also put the plaintiff to proof of the pain, injuries, disability, losses and damages that he claimed.
3          At the end of the three-day trial, I took time to consider the written submissions of counsel.  I found the defendants 75 percent liable for the accident with the plaintiff contributorily liable for 25 percent. 
4          As regards the issue of quantum, I assessed the general damages for the plaintiff’s pain and suffering on a 100 percent basis at $28,500.  I also awarded the plaintiff pre-trial loss of earnings at $13,767.40 and loss of future earnings at $51,600.  The parties had agreed to a sum of $10,000 for future medical expenses, $165 for medical expenses incurred and $200 for transport.  The plaintiff has appealed against the apportionment of liability of 25 percent and the award of $51,600 for loss of future earnings.  The defendants have appealed against the whole of the decision.
The plaintiff’s case
The evidence of Ding Cui Ping, PW1
5          Ding Cui Ping, PW1, was the plaintiff’s co-worker who was carrying out the job of nailing timber runners onto the aluminium I-beams on the scaffold structure together with the plaintiff, at the time the plaintiff fell.  He arrived in Singapore from China and started work at the work site on 5 March 2002.  According to PW1, he was instructed by the defendants’ formworks supervisor, Low Ah Hing, DW1 to nail timber runners along a scaffold structure at the work site on 10 April 2002.  The scaffold comprised 1.9 m high metal frames, with I-shaped aluminium beams installed parallel on two sides of the frame, and were secured by jack-screws.  The beams were supposed to be overlapping and resting on the jack-screws along the scaffold frames.  There were two scaffolds that were about 1.5 m apart and the plaintiff was on the scaffold that was erected over the staircase landing.  Both the plaintiff and PW1 were on the scaffold to nail the timber runners, which were about 4 m long at the time.  PW1 claimed that in the midst of working, he noticed that one of the beams that the plaintiff was working on, was not overlapped at the jack-screw.  Before he could warn the plaintiff, the beam became dislodged and the plaintiff fell about 4 m to the staircase below.  Photographs of structures that were similar to the one on which the plaintiff and PW1 were working at the time of the accident, which were taken by the plaintiff, were exhibited in the plaintiff’s supplementary affidavit of evidence-in-chief at BA131 to 133.  PW1 claimed that after the accident, the formworks supervisor, DW1 asked the rest of the workers to get back to work.  Not long after he had gone back to work, he saw an Indian supervisor from the defendants, taking photographs of the scene of the accident.  He was clearly mistaken, when he stated that the photographs at BA131 to 133 were taken by the defendants’ Indian supervisor.
6          Under cross-examination, his evidence was that he and the plaintiff were the only carpenters who were assigned the job of nailing the timber runners on the scaffold, on 10 April 2002.  The structure, comprising the aluminium beams and jack-screws, was already completed when they were assigned the job.  They started nailing the timber runners in the morning and continued after the lunch break.  Both he and the plaintiff were standing on the aluminium beams when they were nailing the timber runners onto the aluminium beams.  It was his evidence that they would be looking down while they were working.  However, he looked up and noticed that the aluminium beam that the plaintiff was working on was not overlapped, that is, the end of the beam was very near to the metal clamp.  Before he could warn the plaintiff, the beam became dislodged and the plaintiff fell.  PW1 was unable to say whether there were one or two beams at the said metal clamp.  According to PW1, although the beam was dislodged, the structure did not collapse.  He estimated that the height of the structure, which was on the third level, was about 3 m, but the plaintiff had fallen onto the landing between the first and the second level.
7          PW1 and two other workers went to help the plaintiff after the accident.   After DW1 was informed of the accident and had arrived at the scene, the two workers brought the plaintiff to the clinic located opposite the work site and they were subsequently referred to the hospital.  His evidence in re-examination by the plaintiff’s counsel was that after the accident he was told to return to work, when he saw the defendants’ Indian supervisor taking photographs of the scene of the accident.   
The evidence of Yao Zhong Ping,  PW2
8          The plaintiff Yao Zhong Ping, PW2 is a 33 year old Chinese National who arrived in Singapore and commenced work as a construction carpenter with the defendants on 22 August 2001.  His evidence was that on 10 April 2002, he was nailing timber runners at intervals across the aluminium beams on the scaffold at the work site.  As he was moving forward on the scaffold in order to nail the timber runners, one of the beams suddenly gave way and he fell 4 m to the staircase below.  He could not remember what happened after the accident until 9.00 pm the following day. 
9          It was his evidence that he did not know what was stated in the description of accident in the notice of accident (Form A) filed with the Ministry of Manpower by the defendants at PBD 5 to 8, when it was filed.  He alleged in his supplementary affidavit of evidence-in-chief that the defendants’ safety officer, Alexis Eng Jee Inn, DW2, had approached him and asked him to state the account that was stated in the notice of accident, but he did not agree to do so.  It was stated in the notice of accident at PBD8, that he was carrying a bundle of steel bars for fixing the reinforcement for a staircase.  He was walking up the timber formwork, which was wet from the rain, when he slipped and fell forward.  He hit the left side of his face and slipped down the formwork.  He alleged that what was stated in the notice of accident was untrue. 
10        Subsequently, sometime in December 2003 before the interview with the representative from the defendants’ insurers, he was again asked to tell the version that was stated in the notice of accident.  However, he claimed that he gave an account of what had happened on the day of the accident and the statement at DBD5 to 6 was recorded on 13 December 2002.  Under cross-examination, he claimed that although part of the statement was translated to him, it was not translated to him in its entirety and that the part, which stated that “the timber support gave way”, was inaccurate.  He maintained that he and PW1 were standing on the aluminium beams when they were nailing the timber runners and not on the timber runners that have not been nailed yet when he fell.  It was also his evidence under cross-examination that they had started nailing the timber runners since the morning and they had continued with the work after lunch at about 1.00 pm to 1.15 pm.  By the time he fell, the two of them had almost completed the work and there were only about ten or more remaining timber runners to be nailed.
11        After he fell, he was brought to a clinic and subsequently to the Singapore General Hospital (hereinafter referred to as SGH) for treatment.  His external injuries that were noted on 10 April 2002 were: abrasions over right ring finger; and 3 cm laceration lateral to his left eye.  He was discharged on 11 April 2002 after a period of observation and given outpatient medical leave from 11 April 2002 to 13 April 2002.  The medical report from SGH is at PBD 18 to 19.  He returned to work at the work site after the medical leave.  He was assigned to work at another work site at Pasir Ris from 18 May 2002, until he met with a second accident on 26 May 2002.  A metal formwork fell from above and hit his right elbow.  He was treated at Changi General Hospital (hereinafter referred to as CGH) and given medical leave from 27 May 2002 to 3 August 2002.  A copy of the referral for continuation of treatment from CGH is at PBD9.
12        He sought treatment at SGH on 31 May 2002 as he felt some pain in his back, numbness in his lower right leg and experienced bouts of giddiness.  He was discharged with some medication and medical leave for two days.  On 2 July 2002, he went back to SGH and again complained of pain in his back and right knee and numbness of his right lower limb, which had worsened.  The examination showed that there was mild effusion of the right knee and there was some decreased sensation over the L4/L5 nerve root distribution.  He was given oral analgesics and medical leave till 3 July 2002.  An appointment was fixed for him to see a specialist at the Department of Neurology.  He went back to SGH on 12 August 2002 with complaints of right knee and back pain associated with numbness over his right leg.  He was given medical leave till 16 August 2002, his appointment at the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery. 
13        He underwent physiotherapy for three months, but there was no improvement.  He was admitted at SGH on 7 October 2002 for a prolapsed inter-vertebral disc at the L5/S1 level with a right S1 nerve root compression.  He underwent surgery and was discharged ambulating with crutches on 13 October 2002.  On 5 November 2002, he was admitted again to SGH for back pain and sciatica with an inability to walk without support.  He received conservative treatment with analgesics and physiotherapy and was discharge ambulating with crutches on 12 November 2002.  He has produced medical certificates for the following periods: 11 to 13 April 2002, 2 to 3 July 02, 30 July 2002 to 13 August 2002, 12 to 16 August 2002, 16 August 2002 to 27 September 2002 (light duty), 27 August 2002 to 27 October 2002, 23 October 2002 to 4 December 2002, 26 November 2002 to 14 December 2002, 5 December 2002 to 8 January 2003, 11 January 2003 to 23 February 2003, 25 February 2003 to 17 March 2003, 31 March 2003 to 29 April 2003, which are at PBD20 to 36.
14        His evidence was that he was working as a construction carpenter in China for about seven years prior to coming to Singapore on 21 August 2001.  His average income was RMB1,800, which was equivalent to $400, per month.  He has education up to the equivalent of upper secondary level and was only qualified to take on blue-collar jobs.  He claimed that he would be unable to return to work in the construction industry.  He claimed that but for the injury, his income in Singapore should amount to $1,419 per month.  He had only been paid a total sum of $4,970 by the defendants, since April 2002. He claimed that he had incurred $165 for medical expenses and $200 for transport expenses.
The defendants’ case
The evidence of Low Ah Hing, DW1
15        Low Ah Hing, DW1 was the formworks supervisor at the defendants’ work site and the plaintiff’s supervisor at the material time.  His evidence was that the formwork that the plaintiff was building was a platform formwork for the carpenters to stand on top of the platform to carry out their work on the ceiling.  He had asked the plaintiff and PW1 to nail the timer runners onto the aluminium beams on 10 April 2002.  The timber board was to be placed on top of the timber runners and the aluminium beams thereafter.
16        Under cross-examination, he confirmed that the metal frame, jack-screws and aluminium beams had already been installed by another group of workers, before he assigned the job of nailing the timber runners onto the aluminium beams to the plaintiff and PW1.  He was not present when the plaintiff fell.  He claimed that he had inspected the scaffold and found that there was no problem with it, after it was erected.  He did not check the scaffold after the accident, as he was not informed that the scaffold had collapsed.  No one had informed him of any problem with the formwork and the workers continued working there after the accident.  His evidence was that if the aluminium beam was dislodged, the timber runners would have had to be removed and the aluminium beam dismantled and re-installed.  This was not done after the accident, as he was not informed of any problem with the aluminium beams.  However, he admitted that if the jack-screw was not properly secured, it was possible that the aluminium beam could be dislodged. 
17        His evidence was that the workers would have to stand at the beam area at the side of the scaffold while they were nailing the timber runners.  He claimed that there were beams and slabs at the side of the structure, where the timber and plywood had already been done up and the workers could work there.  He also claimed that there were timber barricades at the side so that they would not fall off.  However, he did not notice where the plaintiff and PW1 were standing while they were carrying out their work, when he walked past the area several times that morning.  While his evidence was that the plaintiff could not fall below level two as the landing had been cemented, he confirmed that after the accident, he had found the plaintiff injured at the staircase landing from level one to level two.  According to DW1, the distance between level two and level three was 2.5 m and that between level one and level two, 3m.
The evidence of Alexis Eng Jee Inn, DW2
18        Alexis Eng Jee Inn, DW2 was formerly employed as a safety officer with the defendants.  He was not present at the site at the time of the accident.  He stated in paragraph 3 of his affidavit that he arrived at the scene of the accident after he was informed of the accident on 10 April 2002.  However, under cross-examination, he admitted that he did not go to the scene on 10 April 2002, after the accident.  He also stated in paragraph 5 of his affidavit that he was informed by the plaintiff, that the plaintiff was standing on the timber runner, and was nailing some other timber runner onto the aluminium I-beam, when the timber runner he was standing on slipped and he fell through the gap. 
19        He stated at paragraph 9 of his affidavit that sometime later, the plaintiff had told him that the accident took place as he was carrying a small bundle of steel bars and he had slipped and fallen forward.  He then informed the defendants, who put up the notice of accident dated 3 May 2002 at PBD5 to 8 to the Ministry of Manpower.  He claimed that he subsequently found out that the version stated in the notice of accident was untrue.  The insurers took another statement from the plaintiff on the accident on 13 December 2002.  While he claimed that he believed that what was stated in the notice of accident was the true version at the time, he could not explain his reason for doing so, other than that the plaintiff had told him so.  He also denied that he had asked the plaintiff to lie about the cause of the accident when he was preparing the notice of accident and when the representative from the defendants’ insurers wanted to take a further statement on the accident from the plaintiff.
20        Under cross-examination, he stated that he had investigated the accident by interviewing the witnesses and put up a report in the form of the 9
th
 schedule, which was filed together with the notice of accident.  However, he did not know the reason why his investigation report was not disclosed by the defendants, and he could not remember what the contents of the report.  He claimed that he had spoken with DW1 and one or two of the workers but he could not remember if he had interviewed PW1 about the accident. 
21        Upon being referred to the definition of “scaffold” under the Factories (Building Operations and Works of Engineering Construction) Regulations (Regulation 8, Cap 104), he conceded that the structure that the plaintiff was working on, which was a working platform, would fall within the definition.  He admitted that he did not inspect the structure from which the plaintiff had fallen, either before or after the accident.  According to him, the structure was still in the course of erection when the accident happened.  Although all workers had been issued with safety belts, he was of the view that it was not very practical for the plaintiff to use a safety belt where he was working on the scaffold.  It was also not practical to use a life line or safety netting.  He did not mention any platform or barricades put up at the side of the scaffold for the safety of the workers who were erecting the platform.  He claimed that he had advised the workers to put the timber runners on the aluminium beams randomly, place a plywood board on top of the timber runners and then stand on the plywood.  However, he admitted that the workers could not place a plywood board on top of the timber runners and would have to stand on the aluminium beams, when they were nailing the timber runners onto the aluminium beams.  In any event, it would have been rather dangerous, if the workers had stood on a plywood board that had been placed over timber runners that were placed randomly and not nailed onto the aluminium beams. 
The medical evidence
The evidence of Dr Mark Leong, PW3
22        Dr Mark Leong, PW3, a Consultant with the Department of Emergency Medicine, SGH, confirmed the contents of his report at PBD18 and 19.   Paragraphs 4, 5 and 6 of the report were prepared, based on the records of attendance by other doctors at the Accident and Emergency Department, SGH.  He examined the plaintiff when he was first admitted on 10 April 2002.  PW3 said that, either the plaintiff, or the colleague or the supervisor who had accompanied the plaintiff to the hospital, had informed him that the plaintiff had fallen from a height of 2 m.  PW3’s evidence was that the plaintiff had no recollection of how he was injured at the time.  The plaintiff was conscious “but reported some retrograde amnesia.  He complained of pain over the left side of his head and face.  He did not complain of any pain over his chest, abdomen, pelvis or spine.”  He went on to state, “His neck and spine was non tender.”  Both limbs exhibited full range of movements and external injuries noted were: abrasions over right ring finger and 3-centimetre laceration lateral to left eye.  X-ray showed no fractures of skull and face.  His laceration was sutured and he was admitted for head injury observation.  He was discharged the following morning at 7.23 am to the polyclinic for removal of sutures and given medical leave from 11 to 13 April 2002. 
23        His evidence was that the plaintiff did not have back pain or other symptom at that point of time to indicate that he was suffering a prolapsed disc.  It was his opinion, that it was possible, but unlikely that the plaintiff had suffered a prolapsed disc from the fall, as he did not complain of back pain until some three months later.  He stated that most significant injuries, should surface very early after injury, within hours or a day and symptoms of an acute prolapse of intervertebral disc generally manifest acutely.  However, he stated that it was possible that the bilateral knee pain that the plaintiff complained of on 31 May 2002, may have been related to the L5/S1 prolapsed disc, but rather improbable because there was no back pain.  On 2 July 2002, the plaintiff had complained of right lower leg numbness and right knee pain and there was an indication that the plaintiff had an abnormality in his 4
th
 lumbar and 5
th
 lumbar nerve root distribution.  He was treated with oral analgesics, given medical leave from 2 to 3 July 2002, and a specialist appointment at the Neurology Department.  However, PW3 did not have the records from the Neurology Department with him.  The plaintiff returned on 12 August 2002 with complaints of right knee and back pains, when he was then under the care of the Orthopaedic Surgery Department.
The evidence of Dr John Chen Li Tat, PW4
24        John Chen Li Tat, PW4, the Registrar of the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, SGH first saw the plaintiff on 15 July 2002 and the plaintiff’s main complaint at the time was chronic back pain.  His specialist report on the plaintiff is at PBD53 to 54.  His evidence was that a fall from a height is a significant injury and is likely to result in injury of prolapsed disc.  He confirmed that the bilateral knee pain complained of on 31 May 2002 could have been the result of a fall and could be related to the prolapsed disc.  The complaints of knee pain and lower limb numbness on 2 July 2002 were also indicative of a prolapsed disc. 
25        He then referred to the report of the MRI of the lumbar spine performed on 20 August 2002, which was admitted and marked exhibit P1.  It stated the following comments: “There are two levels of disc degeneration and herniation present.  At the L5/S1 level, there is strong suspicion of compression on the right S1 nerve root.  There is bilateral nerve root canal stenosis seen by no compression on the exiting L5 nerve roots.  At the L4/5 level, the disc herniation is to the right of the midline with possible indentation on the left L5 nerve root…”.  Basically, the plaintiff had two conditions existing: degenerative discs and disc herniation.  Disc herniation is usually related to wear and tear, but is also seen in conditions which involve injury to the back.  PW4 stated initially, that because of the plaintiff’s pre-existing degenerative condition, it would be difficult to prove whether the prolapsed disc was the direct result of injury.  He also stated that symptoms of back pain would present itself immediately or less commonly, within a week or several weeks after the injury.  Subsequently, in answer to questions by the court, he clarified that a prolapsed disc usually presents itself as leg pain, sciatica, rather than back pain.  He went further to state that it is not unusual for a patient with prolapsed disc to have only leg pain without back pain.  A common cause of back pain is due to degenerative disc, which the plaintiff also had.  So when the plaintiff did not present with back pain but presented with leg numbness or weakness, it was quite likely that he had a prolapsed disc following his injury.  He also stated that going by the history and presentation of knee pain six to seven weeks later, it was possible that the injury, that is the fall, had precipitated the prolapsed due to his underlying degenerative disc condition.  He then went on to state that it was probable, based on the presentation of symptoms within six to seven weeks of persistent leg pain lasting several weeks that the fall had precipitated the prolapsed disc.
26        He stated in examination-in-chief that with treatment, he was confident that the plaintiff would be able to recover to perform most of the activities of daily living as well as undertake some form of employment.  He could not state the time required for the plaintiff to recover, but considering his condition at the time, he did not believe that the plaintiff could return to his previous employment in construction.  However, under cross-examination, he stated that given proper treatment, it was possible that the plaintiff would be able to recover to return to being a construction worker within a year or two.  He would recommend that the plaintiff underwent further surgery and physiotherapy.  The costs for the surgery could range from $15,000 to $25,000, based on class B1 rates at SGH.  The plaintiff would also require 6 sessions of physiotherapy, costing about $30 to $50 per session.
The evidence of Dr V Kanda Pillay, PW5
27        Dr V Kanda Pillay, PW5, a Consultant Orthopaedic Surgeon reviewed the plaintiff on 6 January 2003.  His specialist report on the plaintiff is at PBD46 to 48.  The plaintiff informed him that he had fallen from a height of 4 m and lost consciousness.  He still had severe pain in his lower back and right lower limb and had to use 2 axillary crutches.  He could not stand erect and stood in about 20 degree flexion at the hips.  There was hardly any spinal movement and it was not possible to extend his back.  Straight leg raising was 50 degrees on the right and 70 degrees on the left.  He had slight sensory loss in the sole of the right foot and he was acutely tender over the lumbar region.  MRI showed that a L5/S1 laminotomy was done.  The disc was degenerated with marked reduction in the disc space.  There was bulging of the disc and evidence of infection in the disc space and in the adjacent L5/S1 vertebral bodies.  There was also degeneration and protrusion of the L4/5 disc.  The protrusion on the left side, caused a displacement of the thecal sac and a mild left foraminal stenosis.  There was evidence of facet degeneration at the L4/5, as well as the L5/S1 levels. 
28        His opinion was that given the age of the plaintiff, his work history as a construction worker, there was probably early degeneration of the two lumbar discs, the L4/5 and L5/S1 discs.  A fall from 4 m would have caused the L4/5 disc bulge, L5/S1 disc prolapsed and precipitated the acute symptoms.   However, if there had not been a fall, the plaintiff could have carried on working as a manual worker for another 15 to 20 years.  Subsequent to the surgery for the removal of the prolapsed L5/S1 disc, the plaintiff developed a disc space infection as well as osteomyelitis of his lumbar spine at the L4/5 level. 
29        PW5 was of the view that with successful treatment the plaintiff may be able to do some light work, but it was unlikely that he would be able to return to his job as a construction carpenter.  With successful surgery and treatment, the plaintiff would be relieved of the pain, but there would be restriction of movement.  He would only have three discs left and the lower two discs, which are the more mobile ones, would have been fused.  He was also of the view that the prolapsed disc was unlikely to have been caused by the accident on 26 May 2000, when the plaintiff’s elbow was injured.  He stated that even if the plaintiff had fallen while he was standing and taking evasive action to avoid the object that fell on him, it was more likely to have been caused by a fall from height.  The injury to the elbow was also most unlikely to have affected the spine.
The evidence of Dr Anuj Gupta, PW6
30        Dr Anuj Gupta, PW6 was the Medical Officer who attended to the plaintiff on 28 May 2002, one day after he attended at the Accident and Emergency Department, SGH on 27 May 2002.  He prepared the referral for continuation of treatment at PBD9.  His evidence was that x-rays of the injury to the plaintiff’s right elbow did not show any fracture. It was possible that there was soft tissue injury or a very small fracture.  Upon review of the x-rays, Dr Tan HH, saw a small anterior fat pad sign, which could indicate a very small radial head fracture, which was treated conservatively.  He was of the view that the plaintiff’s complaints of vertiginious giddiness and bilateral knee pain on 31 May 2002, did not have any relation to the injury to the right elbow.
Issue of liability of the defendants
31        The plaintiff claimed that the defendants were in breach of their statutory and/or common law duty of care to the plaintiff and pleaded in the particulars of negligence of the defendants, that the defendants had failed:
a)         to ensure that the scaffold was of sound construction and was properly maintained;
b)         to provide a secure foothold and handhold at the place where the plaintiff was working from which he was liable to fall a distance of more than 3 m;
c)         to ensure that suitable means of anchorage for the use of safety belt was provided;
d)         to ensure that a life line was provided;
e)         to ensure that the scaffold was of sound material, good construction and adequate strength;
f)          to ensure that the scaffold was suitable and safe for the purpose for which it was intended;
g)         to ensure that the scaffold was erected by scaffold erectors who have undergone proper training;
h)         to ensure that the scaffold was erected with proper equipment and/or competent workmen;
i)          to ensure that the work site was a safe place of work in ensuring that the scaffold was of sound construction.
32        The plaintiff also relied on the doctrine 
res ipsa loquitur.
  It was noted that although the plaintiff did not specifically plead that the defendants had failed to provide a safe and system of work generally, some of the particulars pleaded related to the system of work.  However, the failure to provide proper supervision was not specifically pleaded.
33        The two main issues of fact that had to be determined were:
a)         Whether the plaintiff was standing on the I-shaped aluminium-alloy beam or on the timber runner when he fell and whether the aluminium beam had given way suddenly or did the plaintiff fall when he slipped while standing on the timber runner;
b)
                 
 
What were the injuries that the plaintiff suffered as a result of the accident and what was the quantum of damages the plaintiff was entitled to if the defendants were in breach of their duty to the plaintiff.
a)         Whether the plaintiff was standing on the I-shaped aluminium-alloy beam or on the timber runner when he fell and whether the aluminium beam had given way suddenly or did the plaintiff fall when he slipped while standing on the timber runner 
34        Whether the structure was a formwork or a scaffold, the defendants had a duty to ensure that the structure was safe for the plaintiff to work on and that there was a safe system of work.  There was no direct evidence as to who were the workers who had erected the structure and whether they were qualified scaffold erectors.  Both PW1 and the plaintiff confirmed that the metal structure, which comprised the metal frames, aluminium beams and jack-screws, was completed before they were instructed to nail the timber runners onto the aluminium beams.  But they were not aware of the identity of the workers who had erected the structure.  The defendants did not dispute that the plaintiff and PW1 were not qualified scaffold erectors.  The plaintiff’s counsel submitted that the defendants were in breach of Regulation 75 of the Factories (Building Operations and Works of Engineering Construction) Regulations.   Regulation 75 provided that scaffolds shall be erected, added to, altered or dismantled by scaffold erectors who have undergone a course of training approved by the Chief Inspector.  In this regard, I would refer to the judgment of the Honourable Chief Justice in the case of 
Mohd bin Sapri v Soil-Build (Pte) Ltd and anor
 
[1996] 2 SLR 505
, in relation to a breach of section 33(7) of the Factories Act at page 519:
“It would be wrong in principle to treat any breach of the Act as if it engendered strict liability for the purpose of claiming compensation in tort.  The issue of causation must be addressed….”
35        The defendants’ formworks supervisor, Low Ah Hing, DW1 alleged under cross-examination, that the plaintiff and PW1 would have been able to stand at the beam area at the side of the structure while they were nailing the timber runners.  He further claimed that there were beams and slabs at the side, where the timber and plywood had already been done up and that there were barricades at the side to ensure that the workers would not fall off.  However, this was not referred to in the defence filed or his affidavit of evidence-in-chief.  The defendants have also not adduced any photographs of the structure where the plaintiff was working on.  The defendants’ safety officer, Alexis Eng Jee Inn, DW2 on the other hand, did not make any reference to this area at the side of the structure where the plaintiff and PW1 could have stood.  In fact, he admitted that while the workmen were nailing the timber runners, they would have to stand on the aluminium beams.  He also admitted that it would not have been practicable for them to use a safety belt, safety line or safety net.
36        Ding Cui Ping, PW1 and the plaintiff claimed that they were standing on the aluminium beam when it gave way and the plaintiff fell.  PW1’s evidence was that the beam that the plaintiff was standing was not overlapped at the joint and that it had dislodged suddenly.  The plaintiff fell before he could warn the plaintiff.  It was his evidence that both workers would be looking down while they were going about their work of nailing the timber runners.  It seemed too much of a coincidence that PW1 would, at the point of time when the beam was about to be dislodged, look in the direction of the beam that the plaintiff was standing on.  He was supposed to have been concentrating on keeping his foot-hold on the aluminium beam and nailing the timber runners onto the beam at the same time.  He had also stated that he went back to work, after the plaintiff was sent to seek medical attention.  He made no mention of having told DW1, about the dislodged aluminium beam or that anything was done to rectify the structure with regard to the dislodged beam.  DW1’s evidence was that there was no report that there was anything that was wrong with the structure.  His evidence was that if the aluminium beam had in fact been dislodged, the timber runners and the aluminium beams would have had to be dismantled and re-installed.  His evidence was that this was not done and that the workers continued working on the structure after the accident without further mishap. 
37        The defendants on the other hand, alleged that the plaintiff had fallen while he was standing on one of the timber runners that have not been nailed and that he fell through the gap.  It should be noted firstly, both DW1 and DW2 were not present when the plaintiff fell.  The defendants did not call their safety supervisor, one Veerasamy, who was allegedly present at the work site at the time and had taken photographs of the scene of the accident thereafter, to give evidence.  DW2 could not offer any reason why Veerasamy was not called as a witness, and an adverse inference could be drawn against the defendants under section 116(g) of the Evidence Act (Cap 97), for their failure to do so. 
38        DW2 alleged that the plaintiff had told him after the accident that he had fallen while he was standing on the timber runner.  However, this was not the description that was stated in the notice of the accident that he had put on behalf of the defendants and was signed by the defendants’ director at PBD8.  He claimed that the plaintiff had told him another version before he filed the notice of accident.  He also claimed that he had put up an investigation report and that the report should have been submitted together with the notice of accident, but he could not remember its contents.  This document was also not adduced by the defendants.  In any event, if it was submitted together with the notice of accident, the account of the accident in the report would have been consistent with the description in the notice of accident.  The defendants did not dispute that the account given in the notice of accident filed by them was not true.  DW2 claimed that he believed that the version in the notice of accident was true at that point of time, but could not offer any reason for his alleged belief.  The plaintiff’s statement at DBD5 that was recorded by the defendants’ insurer’s representative on the other hand, did not state that the plaintiff was standing on the timber runner and that it had slipped, thereby causing him to fall.  It merely stated, “the timber support gave way”.  The plaintiff claimed that there could have been a mistake in the recording of the statement, as the person who recorded the statement did not translate its entire contents to him.  As the defendants did not call the person who recorded the statement to give evidence in rebuttal, the plaintiff’s version would have to be accepted.   There could have been some confusion as to whether the plaintiff had referred to an aluminium support or a timber support.
39        Basically the plaintiff’s evidence was that he was standing on the aluminium beam when it gave way and he fell.  Although PW1’s evidence that he noticed that the aluminium beam was not overlapped at the jack-screw was not credible, and I was not satisfied that the beam had dislodged, I accepted the plaintiff’s and PW1’s evidence that they were standing on the aluminium beams when the plaintiff fell.  For some reason, the plaintiff had lost his balance, slipped and fallen while he was nailing the timber runners to the aluminium beam.  In fact, it would appear that the plaintiff was actually not sure as to how he had fallen from the structure.  PW3’s evidence was that he had no recollection of how he was injured when he was attended to at the SGH. 
40        Having considered the evidence of the four witnesses of fact, I was satisfied that the defendants had failed to provide a safe system of work by requiring the plaintiff to stand on the aluminium beams while nailing the timber runners.  It was also not practicable for the plaintiff to use a safety belt, a safety line or a safety net.  However, although the work may have been dangerous, without a secure foothold and handhold and suitable means to use the safety belt, life line or safety net while working from height, the plaintiff also had to duty to watch out and protect himself from injuries.  In the circumstances, I found that the defendants were 75percent liable and the plaintiff 25 percent contributorily liable for the accident.
b)         What were the injuries that the plaintiff suffered as a result of the accident and what was the quantum of damages the plaintiff was entitled to if the defendants were in breach of their duty to the plaintiff
41        When the plaintiff was examined at the Accident and Emergency Department, SGH on 10 April 2002, he was noted to have sustained abrasions over his right ring finger and 3cm laceration lateral to his left eye.  According to the report by Dr Mark Leong, PW3 at PBD17 to 18, the plaintiff went back to SGH on the following dates: on 31 May 2002 with complaints of vertiginous giddiness and bilateral knee pain; on 2 July 2002 with complaints of right lower limb numbness and right knee pain; and on 12 August 2002 with complaints of right knee pain and back pain.  The plaintiff went to see Dr John Chen Li Tat, PW4 at the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery on 15 July 2002 with symptoms of back pain and numbness in the right limb.  According to the specialist report at PBD53 to 54, there were signs of nerve root tension in the right lower limb and weakness in the big toe and he was diagnosed with a prolapsed disc at L5/S1.  An MRI was done on 20 August 2002 and the report is at exhibit P1.  The plaintiff was admitted at SGH on 7 to 13 October 2002 for surgery, a right sided discectomy at the L5/S1.  On 5 to 12 November 2002, he was re-admitted for recurrence of back pain with left sided sciatica and was unable to walk without support.  He was re-admitted on 11 to 24 January 2003, as his back pain did not improve.  He was examined by Dr V Kanda Pillay, PW5 on 6 January 2003 and the specialist report is at PBD47 to 48.
42        The issue that arose was whether the back injury or prolapsed disc, was caused by the accident.  Although PW3 was of the view that the injury was not likely to have been caused by the fall since that there was no complaint of acute back pain after the fall, he went on to state that the plaintiff’s complaints on 31 May 2002, could have been related to the prolapsed disc.  There was no evidence of any other incident involving the plaintiff, other than the elbow injury caused by a metal formwork that fell on his arm on 26 May 2002.  Both PW5 and PW5 were clear in their view that the prolapsed disc was unrelated to the elbow injury. 
43        PW4 stated initially, that the plaintiff might have had a pre-existing condition of degenerative disc that was aggravated by the fall.  He also stated that although it was possible that the symptoms of back pain may have been delayed, it is well known that patients with acute symptoms from an injury to the back usually present with symptoms of back pain at the earliest onset.  However, under cross-examination, he pointed out that the plaintiff’s complaints of lower leg numbness and right knee pain on 2 July 2002, referred to in paragraph 5 at PBD 19, were related to the prolapsed disc.  In fact, these were subtle signs and symptoms that could have been missed, but were not in this case.  The plaintiff was given a specialist appointment with Neurology.  PW4’s evidence upon clarification by the court as to whether back pain would present immediately, if the disc herniation were caused by injury or trauma was as follows:
“I would say that prolapsed disc usually presents itself as leg pain rather than back pain alone.  Prolapsed disc usually relate to sciatica, leg pain.  It is not unusual for a patient with prolapsed disc to have only leg pain without back pain.  A common cause of back pain is due to degenerative disc, which this patient also has.  So when the patient did not present with back pain, but presented leg numbness and weakness, it is quite likely that he had a prolapsed disc following his injury.”
He finally concluded that it was probable, going by the history and presentation of knee pain six to seven weeks later on 31 May 2002, that the fall on 10 April 2002 had precipitated the prolapsed disc due to his underlying degenerative disc condition.  He went on to state in answer to the defendants’ counsel’s question in clarification the following:
“…I would venture to add that symptoms of prolapsed disc at initial stage does not present with back pain but present with persistent leg pain lasting several weeks.”
44        PW5 also agreed that the plaintiff had a degenerative disc condition and was of the view that the prolapsed L5/S1 disc was more likely to have been caused by a fall from height.  Similarly, for the protrusion at the L4/5 level.
45        Although the views of PW3, PW4 and PW5 as to whether the fall had caused the prolapsed disc at L5/S1 and the protrusion of L4/5, ranged from possible but not probable by PW3, to probable by PW4 and more likely by PW5, all three doctors had linked the plaintiff’s complaints of bilateral knee pain on 31 May 2002, some seven weeks after the fall, to the prolapsed disc.  Both PW4 and PW5 were of the view that presentation of symptom of sciatica within the said period after the fall was not uncommon.  It should be noted that both PW4 and PW5 were Specialist Orthopaedic Surgeons, while PW3 was a Consultant in the Department of Emergency Medicine.  In view of the evidence of PW4 and PW5, I was satisfied on a balance of probability that the prolapsed disc at the L5/S1 level and the protrusion at the L4/5 level of the plaintiff, were caused by the fall from the accident on 10 April 2002.
46        The plaintiff’s counsel submitted that general damages and future medical expenses should be awarded to the plaintiff as follows:
a)         prolapsed inter-vertebral disc at L5/S1 level, infection, aggravation of disc degeneration at L4/5 and facet  degeneration                                                                       $30,000
b)         retrograde amnesia                                                  $ 2,000
c)         3cm laceration lateral to his left eye and abrasions to right ring finger                                                                                                                                         $2,000
d)         7cm incisional scar in lumbar region                           $2,000
e)         future medical expenses (surgery and physiotherapy)  $15,240
47        The defendants’ counsel submitted the following quantum in respect of general damages and future medical expenses:
a)         prolapsed inter-vertebral disc at L5/S1 level, infection, aggravation of disc degeneration at L4/5 and facet degeneration                                                                         $20,000
b)         retrograde amnesia                                                    nil
c)         3cm laceration lateral to his left eye and abrasions to right ring finger                                                                                                                                        $2,000
d)         7cm incisional scar in lumbar region                           nil
e)         future medical expenses (surgery and physiotherapy)  $10,000
The defendants’ counsel confirmed that transport expenses were agreed between the parties at $200 and pre-trial loss of earnings for the period from 10 April 2002 to 10 January 2003 at $7,767.40.  He also confirmed prior to judgment being given that future medical expenses were agreed at $10,000.
48        The plaintiff suffered a prolapsed disc at the L5/S1 level and disc herniation at the L4/5 level.  He underwent a right sided L5/S1 discectomy but experienced recurrence of low back pain following the surgery due to an infection.  As a result, he would have to undergo further surgery to deal with the infection and the protrusion at the L4/5 level.  According to PW5, this would relieve the pain tremendously but there would be restriction of movement of his back, as three of his vertebrae would be fused and immobile.  It was a serious injury to the back, for which the plaintiff would have to undergo in total, two operations.  An award of $25,000 was made by the District Court in the case of 
Zhao Chuan Wang v Straits Construction Company (Private) Limited
 in DC Suit No 3309 of 2001.  I was of the view that a similar award of $25,000, would be appropriate for the pain and suffering and loss of amenities in the present case.
49        The plaintiff also suffered a 3 cm laceration lateral to his left eye and abrasions to his right ring finger and retrograde amnesia for which I awarded the sums of $2,000 and $500 respectively.  An award of $1,000 was also made for the surgical scar.
Loss of earning capacity or loss of future earnings
50        The remaining issue as regards quantum was whether plaintiff should be awarded damages for loss of future earnings or loss of earning capacity.  Dr John Chen Li Tat, PW4 stated in examination-in-chief initially, that in his condition at the time, the plaintiff was unlikely to be able to return to his previous occupation as a construction worker.  However, under cross-examination by the defendants’ counsel, he opined that with further surgery, the plaintiff would be able to return to his job as a construction carpenter within one to two years, although he could not say exactly how long it would take.  PW4 also did not elaborate on the nature of the surgery that would have to be done and the extent of its effect on the plaintiff’s disabilities.  Dr V Kanda Pillay, PW5 on the other hand, was of the view that the plaintiff would not be able to return to work as a construction worker, even after surgery.  He pointed out that although the plaintiff may be relieved of much of the pain, he would still have a stiff back as he would only have three discs instead of five.  As PW4 was not asked to elaborate on the basis for his opinion, PW5’s opinion was preferred and accepted.  Given the circumstances, it would be unlikely that the plaintiff would be able to find useful employment as a construction carpenter either in Singapore or China in the future, even after further surgery and treatment.  He would however, be able to do some light work.
51        The plaintiff’s counsel submitted that the plaintiff was 33 years old and that a multiplier of 15 should be applied.  The plaintiff’s salary in Singapore was $1,000 and his expenses, $250 per month.  His salary in China was about $360 and expenses about $50.  The multiplicand should therefore, be $750 and $310, less $100 for some light work that he would be able to do in China, and the multiplier to be used should be 6 and 9 respectively.  The defendants’ counsel submitted that an award of $25,000 for loss of earning capacity or loss of future earnings would be appropriate in this case.  He was of the view that there was no available evidence on the plaintiff’s earnings and it was uncertain whether his work permit would be renewed.  Further, PW4’s evidence was that the plaintiff would be able to return to normal work after one to two years.
52        Based on PW5’s evidence on the plaintiff’s eventual residual disabilities, I was satisfied that the plaintiff would not be able to return to return to work as construction worker.  With his education and disabilities it was unlikely that he would be able to find a similar job in China.  He may be able to do some low paying light work after surgery and a period of rehabilitation.  As the plaintiff was 33 years old, an award of loss of future earnings using a multiplier of 15 would be appropriate.  I awarded the plaintiff pre-trial loss of earnings at $750 per month from February 2003 to September 2003, a period of eight months, ($750 x 8) amounting to $6,000.  As the loss of earnings from April 2002 to January 2003 had been agreed at $7,767.40, the award for pre-trial loss of earnings amounted in total to $13,767.40.
53        The plaintiff’s work permit expired in August 2003.  Being a skilled worker, he may have been able to obtain a work permit to work in Singapore up to a maximum of ten years.  He may however, not want to stay for such an extended period, because his parents, wife and daughter are in China.  As it was speculative whether his work permit would be renewed and he would want to remain in Singapore to work for the entire balance period, I awarded him loss of future earnings based on his earnings in Singapore for four years from the date of expiry of his work permit.  I would distinguish the case of 
Xu Jing Long v Nian Chuan Construction Pte Ltd
 
[2001] 4 SLR 624
, where the plaintiff was awarded loss of future earnings based on his earnings in Singapore for seven years and his earnings in China for eight years, on the assumption that he would resume working upon his return to China.  In that case, there was evidence that the plaintiff was a good worker with high performance, within the top twenty per cent of the defendants’ workers and that his work permit was likely to have been renewed.  In the present case, there was no evidence as regards the plaintiff’s performance.  The defendants’ counsel submitted that the case 
of Wu Liang Zhu v Chan Yue Ming and Anor
 [unreported, Suit No 291 of 2001 and RA 57 of 2002], where on appeal the award was reduced to 30 percent of the plaintiff’s future earnings, should be applied.  However, the Assistant Registrar had found that the plaintiff would recover fully in about a year’s time in the case.  The final award was made on the basis that the plaintiff would suffer some reduced earning capacity on average over a 17-year period.  In view of my findings based on PW5’s evidence that the plaintiff would not be able to return to work as a construction carpenter even after surgery, I awarded the plaintiff full loss of future earnings for a period of two years.  This was the period that he would require to undergo the operation and rehabilitate to a stage whereby he would be able to do some light work, that is, at $750 per month for 24 months ($750 x 24), amounting to $18,000.  I also awarded him loss of future earnings for another 23 months based on his earnings in Singapore, after taking into consideration an estimated income of  $150 per month for light work that he may be able to do in China ($600 x 23).  This would amount to $13,800.  The award for the remaining period of 11 years for which he would be entitled to loss of future earnings was based on the pay he would have been able to earn in China at $360, after deducting his personal needs at $60, and what he may be able to earn doing light work, at $150 ($150 x 11 x 12), amounting to $19,800.  The award for loss of future earnings therefore, amounted in total to $51,600.
54        In the circumstances, I awarded the plaintiff damages on a 100 percent basis as follows:
General Damages
Pain and suffering                                 $28,500
Loss of future earnings                          $31,800
(Multipler of 4 for Singapore less $150 for light work for 23 months)
Loss of future earnings in China             $19,800
(Multiplier of 11 for China less $150 for light work)
Future medical expenses                        $10,000 (agreed)
Special Damages
Transport                                                $200 (agreed)
Medical expenses                                    $165 (agreed)
Loss of pre-trial earnings                       $13,767.40
$7,767.40 (agreed for April 2002 to January 2003) plus $750 x 6 from February to September 2003
Total:                                                    $104,232.40
At 75%:                                                $ 78,174.80      
In the circumstances, I entered judgment for the plaintiff against the defendants in the sum of $78,174.80; interest at 6% per annum on the sum of  $31,974.30, from the date of issue of writ to judgment and costs. 
Costs
55        The trial which proceeded on both liability and quantum was heard over three days.  One of the main issues was whether the plaintiff’s back injury was caused by the accident on 10 April 2002.  Both counsel tendered written submissions and replies.  I was of the view that a sum of $16,000 plus reasonable disbursements to be taxed, if not agreed would be appropriate, and fixed costs to be awarded to the plaintiff accordingly.
Plaintiff’s claim allowed

title: Public Prosecutor v Teo Yeow Chuah [2003] SGHC 306
content:
Public Prosecutor v Teo Yeow Chuah
[2003] SGHC 306
 
 
Case Number
 
:
 
CC 26/2003
 
 
 
Decision Date
 
:
 
06 December 2003
 
 
 
Tribunal/Court
 
:
 
High Court
 
 
 
Coram
 
:
 
 
Woo Bih Li J
 
 
 
 
Counsel Name(s)
 
:
 
 Jaswant Singh and Terence Tay (Attorney-General's Chambers) for prosecution; S S Dhillon (Dhillon Dendroff and Partners) [briefed] and Chen Chee Yen (Tan Peng Chin LLC) [assigned] for accused 
 
 
 
Parties
 
:
 
 Public Prosecutor — Teo Yeow Chuah 
 
 
 
Criminal Procedure and Sentencing
  – 
Charge
  – 
Particulars
  – 
Whether charge must state fact of death penalty where capital punishment was involved
  – 
Whether accused was aware he was facing capital punishment.
 
 
Criminal Procedure and Sentencing
  – 
Statements
  – 
Admissibility
  – 
Whether accused's long statements were fabricated
  – 
Whether accused's long statements accurately represented what he had said
  – 
Whether accused suffering from withdrawal symptoms when statement pursuant to s 122(6) Criminal Procedure Code (Cap 68, 1985 Rev Ed) was taken.
 
 
 
Introduction
 
 
1          The accused Teo Yeow Chuah was charged with various offences under the Misuse of Drugs Act, Cap 185.  The prosecution proceeded on the first charge which read:
That you, Teo Yeow Chuah, on or about the 29
th
 day of January 2003, at about 7.30 p.m., at the rooftop outside unit #04-01 Fragrance Court, No. 12 Yew Siang Road, Singapore, did traffic in a controlled drug specified in Class ‘A’ of the First Schedule to the Misuse of Drugs Act, Chapter 185, to wit, by having in your possession for the purpose of trafficking, 2 big packets and 89 small packets of substance containing not less than 55.29 grams of diamorphine at the said place, without any authorisation under the said Act or the regulations made thereunder, and you have thereby committed an offence under section 5(1)(a) read with section 5(2) of the Misuse of Drugs Act, Chapter 185, and punishable under section 33 of the Misuse of Drugs Act.
Evidence for the prosecution regarding the arrest of the accused
2          The evidence for the prosecution was that on 29 January 2003, officers from the Central Narcotics Bureau (“CNB”) were instructed to conduct a surveillance on the accused who was known to be driving a gold-coloured BMW bearing registration number SBR 4X. The accused did not own this car and I will refer to it as "SBR 4X". The CNB had received information that the accused and one Lee Siong Lim knew each other and drugs were stored at Fragrance Court (NE  312 to 314). Fragrance Court is a low-rise four-storey apartment block.
3          The accused’s address was Block 515 West Coast Road #12-527. On the way to Block 515, the CNB officers spotted SBR 4X at an Esso petrol kiosk along West Coast Road at about 3.30 pm. 
4          At about 5.20 pm, the accused got into SBR 4X and drove off.  The CNB officers tailed him to a multi-storey carpark at Block 10 Everton Road/Cantonment Close. The accused parked at deck 2B and proceeded to Block 16 and took a lift upstairs.  A while later, he came down with another person (later ascertained to be one Lim Beng Wah) and they walked towards the multi-storey carpark.  At a staircase of the multi-storey carpark, the CNB officers arrested the accused and Lim.
5          The accused was searched and the CNB officers recovered, inter alia, the following items:
(a)        Cash of $2,115
(b)        One red packet containing cash of $12
(c)        One “Nokia” 8250 handphone
(d)        One “Nokia” 8850 handphone
(e)        One bunch of six keys with a “Secura” type key
(f)         One “Louis Vuitton” wallet containing, inter alia, cash of $152
(g)        One plastic bag containing jeans and cargo pants
(h)        One car key with remote control
(i)         A “Marlboro” cigarette box which contained:
(i) a sachet of heroin
(ii) a straw of heroin
(iii) a rolled-up piece of paper, and
(iv) a piece of tin foil
(see Photo P31).
6          Station Inspector (“SI”) Ang Oon Tho, also known as Jimmy Ang, then questioned the accused in Hokkien as to whether he had any drugs in SBR 4X.  The accused admitted he had drugs which were at the driver’s door.  The accused was then brought to SBR 4X and ten sachets of heroin wrapped in paper were recovered from the side pocket of the driver’s door.  An “Elsema” remote control was also recovered from the car.  The accused said this was for opening the main gate to Fragrance Court.
7          The CNB officers then escorted the accused to Fragrance Court.  They arrived there at about 7.30 pm.  The accused led the CNB officers to the unit at #04-01. On entering the unit, SI Ang asked the accused whether there was any drug inside his bedroom and he replied “No”.  The accused led the CNB officers to his bedroom which was on the second level of #04-01. I will refer to his bedroom as "the Bedroom". The door to the Bedroom was not locked.
8          SI Ang then conducted a search of the Bedroom and found the following:
Inside, but at the top, of the wardrobe (see the location marked B in Photo 7)
(a)            A white plastic bag containing some empty sachets
(b)        A red plastic bag containing some rubber gloves
(c)        an empty sealer box
Inside a drawer beneath the platform bed
(d)        a plastic container and spoon believed to be stained with heroin
On the floor
(e)        A “Ghostbusters” magazine with several pages missing.
9            Thereafter SI Ang climbed out of the Bedroom through a window which had no lock and which led to the rooftop of Fragrance Court.  He searched the rooftop and found a knotted black plastic bag (which is sometimes referred to as  a trash bag). This plastic bag was found almost at one end of the rooftop behind a pillar.  It was below the eves of a tiled roof.  It was found at a location marked ‘A’ (see Photo P3 and P4 and the sketch plan, P33, drawn by Staff Sergeant Chua Yue Meng).
10        Inside the plastic bag was a black Oakley sports bag (see Photo P14 and P15).  The zip of the Oakley bag was secured with a padlock.
11        SI Ang then brought the plastic bag with the Oakley bag into the Bedroom and showed these items to the accused.  When questioned, the accused admitted that the Oakley bag belonged to him. 
12        SI Ang's conditioned statement (paragraph 15) stated that he had asked the accused for the key to the padlock securing the zip of the Oakley bag and the accused informed him that the key was among the bunch of six keys recovered from him earlier. SI Ang then recollected and brought out the bunch of six keys seized from the accused earlier and he then tried the keys in turn until one of them opened the padlock. 
13        After the padlock was opened, the contents of the Oakley bag were checked in the presence of the accused.  They were:
Main compartment
(a)        A bundle of substance wrapped in paper. The substance was believed to be heroin.
(b)        A “Soda” brand plastic bag containing two bundles of substance wrapped in paper. The substance was believed to contain heroin.
(c)        An “M1” brand paper bag containing:
(i) Eight packets, each containing ten sachets of substance wrapped in paper. The substance was believed to be heroin.
(ii) One packet containing nine sachets of substance wrapped in paper. The substance was believed to be heroin.
(d)        A white plastic bag containing:
(i) A brown envelope containing a weighing scale
(ii) A black plastic bag containing a second weighing scale
(iii) A blue-colour bag containing a third weighing scale
(e)        A sealer
Side pocket
(f)         A metal spoon
(g)        A pincer
(h)        A cutter
(i)         Some empty sachets
(j)         Some empty plastic bags
(k)        A roll of scotch tape
(l)         A plastic container
(m)       A pair of pliers
(n)        A blade
(o)        A white envelope containing three yellow-colour and one blue-colour tablet believed to be “Ecstasy”.
14        SI Ang said he questioned the accused about the ownership of the drugs and items found in the Oakley bag. The accused admitted that the drugs and items all belonged to him. 
15        Then, at about 8 pm, SI Ang asked the accused a few questions. At this time, Mandarin was used. The questions and answers were recorded in SI Ang’s pocket book in Chinese with an English translation.  The English translation read:
Q1: All the “Peh Hoon” found in your body belong to whom
A1: Mine
Q2: The 10 sachets of “Peh Hoon” found inside your vehicle belong to whom
A2: Mine
Q3: The 10 sachets of “Peh Hoon” is for what purpose
A3: For my own consumption
Q4: All the “Peh Hoon” found inside the bedroom belong to whom
A4: Mine
Q5: How much “Peh Hoon” are there
A5: About 4 bundle
Q6: All the “Peh Hoon” is for what purpose
A6: For selling
Q7: Who is the male Chinese in red T-shirt
A7: Ah Siong
Q8: Does “Ah Siong” related to the drugs found inside the room
A8: No related
Q9: What relationship you and “Ah Siong”
A9: Friend
Q10: Did you sell “Peh Hoon” to “Ah Siong”
A10: Yes
Q11: When is the last time you sold “Peh Hoon” to “Ah Siong”
A11: Yesterday
Q12: How many sachets
A12: Twenty
Q13: How much
A13: Five hundred per sachet
16        The accused denied that his answers to Questions 4 and 6 were made voluntarily and so a voir dire or trial within a trial was conducted to determine the admissibility of these answers.
The Voir Dire (Trial within a trial)
17        The accused claimed that his answers to Questions 4 and 6 were the result of a threat or inducement.
18        Prior to the recording of the accused’s statement, he was brought to the door of the Bedroom and asked to identify a person who had been arrested.  This was his friend Lee Siong Lim, also known as Ah Siong. From the accused's long statements, which I will come to subsequently, Ah Siong is also known as Roger. I will refer to this person as "Ah Siong" or "Roger". Ah Siong was at the first floor of the unit in the living room and he was handcuffed, as was the accused.
19        Also, prior to the recording of the accused’s statement, SI Ang had asked one of the officers, Sgt Jack Foo, to leave the Bedroom leaving only S/Sgt Tony Ng, SI Ang and the accused in the Bedroom.
20        When SI Ang was giving evidence for the voir dire, the accused’s position was as follows. When Question 4 was asked, the accused had hesitated and looked at SI Ang because Question 4 was “All the “Peh Hoon” found inside the bedroom belong to whom” whereas in fact no drugs were found inside the Bedroom.  Then, SI Ang said to the accused “All the "Peh Hoon” in the bedroom is yours right?” in a threatening manner.  The accused again looked at SI Ang and had a confused expression.  SI Ang then told him that he had already admitted to the drugs in the first three questions and if he did not admit to those in the Bedroom, SI Ang would also charge everybody who had been to the Bedroom.  SI Ang also told the accused that the accused had earlier seen Ah Siong handcuffed and threatened to charge Ah Siong, Ah Siong’s wife, the accused’s girlfriend and the accused’s entire family if the accused did not admit that the heroin in the Oakley bag belonged to him.  The accused then responded, “OK, it’s mine” (NE 261 to 264).
21        SI Ang denied:
(a)        that the accused had hesitated or showed any confused expression,
(b)        that he (SI Ang) had said that all the “Peh Hoon” in the Bedroom was the accused’s,
(c)        that he had told the accused that he had already admitted to the drugs in the first three questions and if the accused did not admit to the drugs in the Bedroom, he would charge everyone who had been to the Bedroom,
(d)        he had told the accused he had earlier seen Ah Siong handcuffed and threatened to charge Ah Siong, Ah Siong’s wife, the accused’s girlfriend and the accused’s entire family if the accused did not admit that the heroin in the Oakley bag belonged to him, and
(e)        that, in response to SI Ang’s threat, the accused said, “OK, it’s mine”
(NE 261 to 264).
22            However, SI Ang accepted that in fact no drugs were found in the Bedroom.  He explained that he meant to refer to the drugs found on the rooftop which had since been brought into the Bedroom and he had pointed to the Oakley bag when he asked Question 4 (NE 264 to 265). Accordingly, the accused knew that SI Ang was referring to the drugs in the Oakley bag.
23        As for the answer to Question 6, the accused’s position was that when the question was posed to him, he again hesitated.  SI Ang then said, “So much of ‘Peh Hoon’, must be for selling.  Don’t tell me it is not for selling”.  The accused then replied, “OK, for selling”.
24        Again, SI Ang denied:
(a)        that the accused had hesitated before answering Question 6,
(b)        that he (SI Ang) had suggested that the ‘Peh Hoon’ must be for selling, and
(c)        that the accused had responded “OK, for selling”
(NE 275).
25        SI Ang had also said that it was his superior ASP Xavier Lek who had called him to instruct him to see if the accused could identify Ah Siong and this instruction was received before he recorded the statement of the accused.  Accordingly, he did as he was instructed (NE 256 and 257).  On this point, ASP Xavier Lek gave evidence which corroborated SI Ang’s evidence that it was ASP Xavier Lek who had instructed SI Ang to see if the accused could identify Ah Siong and it was he who instructed SI Ang to record a statement from the accused after Ah Siong had been identified (NE 307 to 308, 315 to 316).
26        In addition, SI Ang said he did not know whether the accused’s parents were still living or whether the accused had siblings or a girlfriend although he knew that Ah Siong had a wife (NE 279 to 280). 
27        Staff Sergeant Tony Ng Tze Chiang also gave evidence.  He was in the Bedroom guarding the accused when the accused’s statement was recorded by SI Ang.  S/Sgt Tony Ng confirmed that the questions and answers were in Mandarin which he (S/Sgt Tony Ng) understood.  He could not recall the exact questions and answers nor each and every detail of the recording session but the accused was acting normally and SI Ang’s tone of voice was normal as well (NE 291 to 292, 298 and 302).  He said that SI Ang did not threaten the accused during the session nor tell the accused that his girlfriend, Ah Siong's wife and the accused’s entire family would be charged if he did not admit to a particular question (NE 291 to 292).  He accepted that he was not observing the accused throughout the recording (NE 303).
28        The accused was the only witness for the defence in respect of the voir dire.  He left school when he was ten years old and had fended for himself since (NE 350).   He referred to Ah Siong as a friend (NE 323) and then a good friend, (NE 324) and also, a close friend (NE 372).  They had known each other for a couple of years (NE 324).  He confirmed that when he was brought to the Bedroom, a search was conducted of the Bedroom.  Thereafter, SI Ang climbed out of the window of the Bedroom and subsequently returned with the Oakley bag inside the plastic bag.  SI Ang asked him some questions and he had said that the Oakley bag was his. He denied that he had told SI Ang that the key to the padlock was among the six keys seized. SI Ang then opened the Oakley bag and took out its contents and showed them to the accused, as wrapped (NE 327 to 329).  Then SI Ang brought him to the entrance of  the Bedroom to identify Ah Siong who was downstairs in the living room and was handcuffed.  He said he did not know why Ah Siong was shown to him for identification (NE 346, 347 and 363).  The accused was then brought back into the Bedroom.  Previously there were two other officers in the Bedroom, besides SI Ang and S/Sgt Tony Ng.  One had left the Bedroom earlier and the other, Sgt Jack Foo, was asked by SI Ang to leave before the recording of the accused’s statement.  SI Ang then began recording the accused’s statement and the remaining officer S/Sgt Tony Ng took no part in this exercise (NE 333).
29        The accused said that when Question 4 was posed to him, he stared at SI Ang blankly because no drugs were found in his Bedroom (NE 335).  He did not initially realise that SI Ang was asking about the drugs in the Oakley bag (NE 365).  SI Ang then told him that since he had already admitted to the first three questions, it was better for him to admit to Question 4 as well.  SI Ang added that if the accused did not admit to Question 4, he would charge Ah Siong, Ah Siong's wife, the accused’s girlfriend, his family as well as those who had come to the unit at Fragrance Court (NE 337).  The accused then replied, “All right, OK, it’s mine”.
30        The accused claimed that when SI Ang posed Question 4 to him and told him he might as well admit to it and threatened him about charging others, he (the accused) was very confused and afraid because he did not know what SI Ang was referring to as no drugs were found in his Bedroom.  SI Ang was fierce and he was very frightened (NE 337).  However, he also said that when he gave his response, he knew that SI Ang was referring to the drugs in the Oakley bag (NE 375, 383 and 385).  He also said that when he gave his response, he did so as he was the one who consumes drugs and he did not want the drugs to implicate his family and friends.  He said he believed SI Ang would charge others as SI Ang was a policeman (NE 337 to 338).
31        As for Question 6, the accused said that when this question was asked, he just stared blankly and SI Ang then told him that as so much heroin was found, it must definitely be for sale.  SI Ang told him not to tell SI Ang otherwise and the accused replied by saying that they were for sale.  He said he was still very confused and frightened that his family would be implicated.  SI Ang was still very fierce (NE 343). After the statement was recorded, the accused was lying on the bed but was not asleep as he was craving for drugs (NE  379, see also 704).
32        In submission, the defence sought to make much out of the fact that the accused was shown Ah Siong before his statement was recorded.  The suggestion was that this was done so that the sight of Ah Siong being handcuffed would remain in the accused’s mind to intimidate him into giving such answers as SI Ang wanted from him. Accordingly, the accused did feel threatened when SI Ang subsequently uttered the threat to charge everyone and in particular Ah Siong, Ah Siong’s wife, the accused’s girlfriend and his entire family and all else who had been to #04-01 at Fragrance Court.
33        I was mindful that certain aspects of SI Ang's evidence were not satisfactory. He had said he could remember every question and answer for the arrests he was involved in between January 2003 to July 2003. He could also remember the questions he had posed for the last 23 years he had been with CNB (NE  224). It seemed to me that that was a gross exaggeration. However, the accuracy of his notes was not in question and also I considered his evidence in totality. I also considered the evidence of ASP Xavier Lek, S/Sgt Tony Ng and the accused, as well as the background circumstances leading to the accused's responses to Questions 4 and 6.
34        It was clear to me that when SI Ang posed Question 4, the accused knew that SI Ang was referring to the drugs in the Oakley bag which had since been brought into the Bedroom from the rooftop outside.  I did not believe that the accused did not know what SI Ang was referring to initially or that the accused stared blankly at SI Ang when Question 4 was posed to him. It was clear to me that the accused was seeking to take undue advantage of the manner in which Question 4 was framed.
35        I also did not accept that SI Ang even uttered the threat suggested or that the accused had been frightened by it. There was no reason for SI Ang to utter the threat because the accused had not yet denied that the drugs in the Oakley bag belonged to him.  Up to the time just before Question 4 was asked, the accused had been co-operative, a point which the defence itself had stressed.  He had already admitted readily that the drugs found in one of his trouser pockets and in SBR 4X  were his.
36            Secondly, SI Ang did not even know that the accused had a girlfriend or whether the accused’s family was still alive and who comprised the family.  How then could he have mentioned the accused’s girlfriend and family in the threat? 
37            Besides, unlike the case of 
Poh Kay Keong v PP
   
[1996] 1 SLR 209
, the drugs in the Oakley bag were not found in premises occupied by any member of the accused’s family, or occupied by Ah Siong for that matter.  Indeed, no drugs were found at the accused's mother’s residence at West Coast Road and to the best of the accused’s knowledge, no one else in his family consumed drugs (NE 368).  So he would not have expected drugs to be found in any of the homes of his siblings. Taking this into account, and the accused's demeanour in court, I was of the view that the accused would not have been intimidated even if the threat had been made.
38        As for the accused’s identification of Ah Siong, it was clear to me that the defence had been trying to make too much out of it.  In the first place, SI Ang undertook the identification exercise on the instructions of ASP Xavier Lek.  Unless the defence was suggesting that ASP Xavier Lek had planned or conspired with SI Ang to put pressure on the accused, the exercise of identifying Ah Siong before the accused’s statement was taken was quite innocent.  On this point, I noted that while Mr S S Dhillon, Counsel for the defence, sought to question ASP Lek as to why he had given such an instruction, Mr Dhillon stopped short of making the suggestion I have mentioned.  Besides, even the accused said he did not know why he was asked to identify Ah Siong (NE 346, 347 and 363). The accused did not suggest that Ah Siong was shown to him in order to intimidate him. There was also no suggestion by Mr Dhillon to SI Ang or S/Sgt Tony Ng that the accused had become intimidated after he was shown Ah Siong in handcuffs.
39            Although the defence also sought to make something out of the fact that SI Ang asked Sgt Jack Foo to leave the Bedroom before the statement was recorded, the fact of the matter was that there was still one other officer present i.e. S/Sgt Tony Ng who was guarding the accused. Indeed, I was impressed by the honest answers from S/Sgt Tony Ng. Initially, some changes in his evidence made him appear an unreliable witness but it gradually became apparent that he was changing his evidence to be as accurate as he could when he realised his earlier evidence might have given the wrong impression. As I have said, he admitted candidly that he could not remember every question and answer exactly nor was he observing the accused all the time throughout the recording of his responses to SI Ang's questions.
